#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Store a Car for Winter

#Text=Whether you are heading down south for an extended winter vacation , headed off to a semester at college , or just ca n’t imagine using your convertible when there is a windchill , there are dozens of great reasons to store your car for the winter .
#Text=While there are potential issues with storing your car for an extended time , there are plenty of ways to prepare your car for hibernation .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Preparing the Exterior of Your Car
#Text=Wash and wax your car .
#Text=Giving your car a thorough external detail before storing it will help protect your paint from salt and moisture .
#Text=Be sure the car is completely dry before storing it or you could trap moisture under the storage material , potentially causing damage to your car ’s exterior .
#Text=Hand washing , rather than a commercial wash , is recommended .
#Text=You also want to polish any chrome on the outside of your vehicle .
#Text=Do n't neglect the undercarriage .
#Text=Stop by your local automotive shop for some rubberized undercoating or WD-40 ; spraying either of these on the underside of your car will provide lasting protection .
#Text=Be sure you wash your car before waxing it .
#Text=How you wax your car will depend on whether you are applying the wax by hand or by electronic buffer .
#Text=Fill tires with extra air .
#Text=Before storing your vehicle , check the pressure on the tires .
#Text=Filling the tires with a little extra air will help prevent the tires from going flat .
#Text=You can also store your vehicle on jackstands to avoid putting any pressure on the tires .
#Text=However , many vehicle frames do not respond well to this type of storage , so it ’s best to check with a local mechanic before taking advantage of this option .
#Text=You can also put 2x10 inch blocks of wood beneath each tire to help ease the pressure of parking on concrete .
#Text=Select a waterproof cover .
#Text=Selecting a quality cover for your car is important because dust and grime can build up and eventually damage your car 's exterior .
#Text=A normal sheet or dust cover will do little to maintain your vehicle .
#Text=When deciding what cover to use choose be sure it ’s waterproof and made of a breathable material .
#Text=Be sure to never use a tarp to store your vehicle .
#Text=It will scratch your paint and trap moisture against your car .
#Text=If you are able to store your car in a garage , the cover is not as necessary .
#Text=Caring for the Engine and Other Internal Mechanisms
#Text=Fill the tank .
#Text=Leaving your gas tank empty will lead to unwanted moisture buildup which can easily cause your tank to rust or clog .
#Text=The more gas you have in your tank , the less air space , and the less you have to worry about .
#Text=You may also want to purchase a fuel stabilizer if you are storing your car for longer than three months .
#Text=Check fluids like oil and antifreeze .
#Text=It ’s best to change your oil and oil filter before storing , giving your car a fresh reservoir to work with .
#Text=It 's also essential to top off the antifreeze because it will help your vehicle maintain the same level of efficiency and power when you restart it .
#Text=Put boxes of baking soda under the hood .
#Text=Moisture is your car ’s worst nightmare during storage season .
#Text=Soak up any extra moisture by putting 2-4 boxes of baking soda in various places beneath the hood .
#Text=Store your battery separately .
#Text=Store the battery in a warm room as cold batteries tend to crack .
#Text=In order to disconnect your battery , first identify the negative terminal which will be marked by black plastic and a minus sign .
#Text=Use pliers or a wrench to secure and then remove the negative .
#Text=Repeat this process for the positive terminal .
#Text=Once you 've removed the nuts , remove the bracket holding your battery in place using your wrench or pliers .
#Text=Now all you have left to do is lift the battery out and move it to a warm , dry location .
#Text=Before removing the battery , be sure your car is off , and your gloves and goggles are on .
#Text=You should also be wary that the positive and negative cables do not touch .
#Text=Also , do not let the positive nut touch any metal as it could be potentially dangerous .
#Text=If you choose to keep the battery in the car , you will need to have someone start it every few weeks so that the battery does not lose its charge .
#Text=Maintaining the Interior of Your Car
#Text=Use seat covers and desiccant to avoid moisture buildup .
#Text=The cabin of your car is as prone to moisture damage as the rest of your vehicle .
#Text=Slipping seat covers on the seats and tossing a few cheap packets of desiccant on the floorboard can help defend against potential damage .
#Text=It ’s also important to steam clean the interior far in advance of storage , since the steam will leave a fair amount of moisture behind .
#Text=Store dryer sheets and mothballs in the cabin .
#Text=Mice and other small rodents love to make homes out of inactive vehicles .
#Text=Throw a couple dryer sheets and mothballs soaked in peppermint in or on your car to help deter these unwanted roommates .
#Text=You can also set traps , but only outside of the car : a dead mouse decomposing in your car is not going to lead to an easy spring transition .
#Text=You can also put steel wool in the pipes to prevent critters from climbing in .
#Text=Do n’t set the parking break .
#Text=For many people pulling the parking break is a habit , but with an extended period of time there is a possibility that your brake pads could meld to your rotors .
#Text=You can purchase a tire stopper if you are worried about the car ’s movement .
#Text=Detail the car 's interior .
#Text=Vacuum your car and remove all trash .
#Text=Wrappers and food particles that are left behind will attract animals and lead to mold if left unattended .
